Keynsian theory refers to increasing government spending as a TEMPORARY remedy to close an output gap (caused by severe fall in aggregate demand) DURING A RECESSION. I never said I could teach music, and I don't see how that's relevant. The point is that I have enough understanding of the concepts required to learn music to make an informed judgement on whether or not your analogy is logically consistent and it isn't.

By contrast, something like the relationship between people, corporations and governments is immensely complicated and something that we simply don't have enough data on to make the short, simple, black and white assertions such as the ones you are making.

I don't understand how you can possibly imagine characterising the relationship between people, corporations and governments as simple. I am a musician myself, and just because music is abstract does not mean the concepts that someone has to learn in order to understand it on a functional level are complicated. Most concepts involved in teaching young kids music are things like how to read rhythm, pitch and so on, things that follow consistent, rules that are easy to follow once learned.

No, there's nothing about your point of view that I have trouble understanding. At least I don't think there is, correct me if my responses suggest otherwise. I do think that my point of view on this issue is significantly more complicated than yours, and I prefer to explain my rationale for my beliefs as comprehensively as I can. By what mechanism do you suggest people would be able to deal out retribution to corporations? In a government free system there would be nothing stopping them from gaining monopolies on things as basic as food and water, or from controlling large armed forces. You cannot boycott a company if they have a monopoly on clean drinking water and you can't attempt to fight a company that has a monopoly on weapons.

My previous two comments are something of an oversimplification, but this topic is really too complex for a 500 character format.

If certain checks are in place(checks that are notably absent in the USA), it is possible to make government relatively free of corporate control and corruption, and to ensure they serve the people. If corporations aren't able to make huge campaign contributions in exchange for officials protecting their intrests, and the public is as informed as possible, the only thing that elected officials will be competing for is who can act in a way that is most approved by the public.

I never said anything to suggest that the government is above criticism, or that they should just be blindly trusted. The point here is that at least in theory, a moral government could exist. This is not true for corporations in a capitalist society. Corporations are amoral. They will do terrible, horrible things if it is profitable for them to do so. If they don't, their competitor does and outcompetes them. The only thing that has any power to prevent this is a government.

If you decide to respond and ask questions, please be courteous. I have given a lot of thought to my position. I recognize that it is not mainstream. And yes, I recognize the government currently provides services that people like, want, or need. 

I just believe the means by which they are funded and enacted are immoral, inefficient, and can be addressed differently.

The role of a government is not to supply things the private sector cannot, but to regulate the way the private sector is allowed to work. You cannot have a capitalist economy without someone in control, making sure we don't fuck ourselves over, and keep the greed at least marginally in check. This is the role of the government, and I don't see how you could persist without it.

Otherwise the discussion is going to continue to have some serious scope creep.
I do agree with you on this point.

If you're interested in actually having a discussion about this, please try not to do more than two responses at once. Youtube's comment threading sucks and it's hard to track more than two threads. :/ 

Also - I am not interested, at the moment, in discussing the nature of whether or not the government has the *RIGHT* to tax. Like I keep saying, that is a separate discussion to be had another time.

That's not exactly how I phrased it.

Paying taxes is the law. That is a fact. Whether or not the lawmakers have the defactor authority to create said laws is another discussion.

"Skirting this law...is wrong" is a separate premise. I argue that it is wrong to do this because these companies benefit from the things that taxes PROVIDE but believe that they do not need to contribute to the funds that provide them. If a company wishes to not pay taxes, it should not enjoy any of the fruits of tax.

But again - that is all an entirely different line of discussion. 

The point I made earlier is simply "a corporation does business in the US, but exploits certain rules so that it minimizes its obligation in a way that affects the rest of us", and I believe this is wrong.

I think you are being overly-semantic here. I agree with you on a superficial level, but disagree with your point. 

A "nation" exists as a construct that we use for bookkeeping purposes (similar to a "Corporation", really), much in the same way that "red" is the name we assign to a specific wavelength of light. "red" doesn't actually exist. Nor does "color" really. 

FWIW, I don't vote Rep or Dem, but I accept the reality that, since I live here, I must abide by certain rules, or act to change.

OK I understand the point you are making here. IMHO, public goods are best provided through the public sector, that's what I meant.

However, my main point was simply that the businesses are required to pay taxes; that's the law. Skirting this law, even under grey-areas, is wrong, even if it makes economic sense to their fiduciary duty. The actions of our constituents, both human and corporate, affect us all in one way or another, so it would be myopic to not consider the ramifications of this.

Also, please cite the multiple logical fallacies you believe I committed in my prior post. (Both the allegedly fallacious point I made as well as the named fallacy I committed)

The only logical proposition I wrote was that "something that makes economic sense does not necessarily make good [moral] sense", providing FLSA / Child labor laws as supporting examples.
How may an independent contractor take advantage of this......:)

You fail at understanding what "logic" is, in this case (and spelling too, if we're being pedantic). 

Taxation is the price we pay for living in an organized society. I happily pay my income/payroll taxes because I enjoy having access to clean water, air, public facilities & services, and I want others to enjoy that as well.

Corporations that exploit tax havens in order to minimize their legally-required obligation (and, I would argue, moral obligation to their country), are committing theft.

A company that has the privilege of doing business in the US should not be allowed to "shop around" for its tax rate. If you want to do business here and sell your products here (thus taking advantage of American demand and American infrastructure) then you pay our taxes. Plain and simple.

Just because something makes "economic" sense doesn't make it a "good" thing to do. This is one of the reasons we have child labor laws and the FLSA.
